text: um
hi everyone sweetheart tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new rex orange
county album who cares this is a brand
new lp from alex o'connor aka rex orange
county a singer-songwriter who is now on
his fourth full-length lp the follow-up
to his 2019 major label debut pony a
project that did receive some mixed
reactions from fans and critics alike
many of whom may have expected something
different given the more bedroom pop
leanings of rex's earlier works which i
can't speak to personally as i didn't
rant and rave about those albums when
they dropped my first intro to rex
orange county was obviously through his
inclusions on tyler the creator's
flowerboy but i still wasn't crazy about
pony myself though yeah there were some
killer tunes on the track list like 10
out of 10 but something definitely felt
missing from this project the production
sure sounded clean maybe more
professional in comparison with rex's
earlier works but the writing and
performances and instrumentation came
off much more measured on this project
really to a fault essentially i left
pony feeling like rex had a better
record in him and personally i think who
cares is that better record it was
pretty clear from the outset that this
was going to be a different musical
experience given the first taste that we
had of the project keep it up this track
felt like a good balance between the
lush and beautiful instrumentation that
made apricot princess so good but then
also the direct and cut and dry
songwriting that rex was attempting on
pony plus there are some genuine
feelings of self-encouragement and
acceptance being wrestled with in the
lyrics and the track sounds like the
theme song to a 90s family sitcom in the
best way possible there may still be a
lasting sentiment among some rex fans
that oh this doesn't sound exactly like
the old old stuff i wish he would kind
of bring that back which i get but
simultaneously i would say rex is
absolutely nailing it on this track in
every way that he can like with pony
many of the songs from here operate on a
bass line of very simple beats and
instrumentation but the mixes offer a
bit more punch and weight more to bite
into and all of these sampled string
sections brought by close collaborator
benny sings on this record who is pretty
much on this thing from front to back
they really elevate the writing on these
tracks immensely playing off rex's
constant lyrics about escapism and
self-acceptance in a bittersweet way
cause on the surface a lot of this lp
sounds very pretty very happy-go-lucky
but dig a little bit deeper on this
project and you'll see the emotions here
are locked in a series of internal
struggles eventually leading to a
gratifying conclusion on the title track
which is a song that's very much about
overthinking things and
self-consciousness and allowing yourself
to let go and be happy instead so who
cares has a really great run of cuts in
the first half open a window is great
from front to back the soul-inspired
lead vocals and chord changes these
string sections are on point plus they
match really well with the subtly growly
tone of the bass and groovy beats the
tyler feature on the back end is not
just good but also a very natural fit
showing just how much creative common
ground rex and tyler have the string
sections on worth it sound like
something straight out of a fairy tale
which makes for some theatrical vocal
passages where it sounds like rex is
giving a performance in the midst of a
musical which contrasts well with the
funkier drum and bass bits that are
laced with touches of woodwind from here
we have a one-two combo of love songs
that lay the sweetness on heavy don't
change a thing you are amazing you're
one in a million again really good
highlights but from here in the second
half is where stuff gets tough i
wouldn't say the quality of the project
drops off exponentially or anything like
that but i can tell that rex and benny
are struggling a little bit to find
footing bringing some much needed
versatility to this project cause really
how many sad but saccharine string
ballads can you do especially when
you've set the bar so high on the opener
we have the very tense and moody if you
want it where the strings are swapped
out for synths it's an interestingly
dark change of pace yes but i still wish
there was more progression across the
track it does come off a bit
one-dimensional i mean as long as we're
changing maybe this might be a time to
incorporate some of the explosive and
visceral strides that made apricot
princess some tracks on that record so
interesting because like with pony there
are some pockets of this lp that come
off a bit too measured 7am brings
another ballad another helping of pretty
instrumentation but the lyrics on this
one purely show rex just wallowing in
his own misery
and self-doubt in a way that is a little
difficult to stomach making time is the
shortest cut here in a very stripped
back a little guitar number that is kind
of raw on the production side uh while i
guess it is another change of pace it's
not a terribly exciting one maybe this
stark shift would have hit harder had
the previous song been a bit more grand
in tone or presentation but with that
being said this record does have a very
strong ending with the song shoot me
down which is a genuinely
heart-wrenching piano ballad with some
grand chord progressions a thick groove
the instrumental is vivid the vocal
performance is emotionally potent the
vibe of the song is down but not out as
depressing as the song is
rex is still striving for something on
this one there's still hope that he's
fighting for and that's where i think
much of this record's magic comes out in
its storytelling that tension of being
in an in-between place i am very well
aware of my surroundings and my
situation i'm not happy with it i hate
it but i'm going to fight to put myself
in a better position in a better spot be
that emotionally and mentally or
interpersonally and then the title track
that i mentioned earlier is a very
gratifying finish for the entire lp
closes things up thematically in terms
of all of the emotional struggles that
rex had been going through on track
after track up until this point and
coming away from this track and this
record in general i hope rex can
actually embody the attitudes and the
feelings that he is broadcasting on
songs like this allowing him to
transition into a point in his career
where he can actually feel freer
creatively and not have to worry so much
about what people are are thinking or
saying that being said there are some
tracks i'm not crazy about there are
also issues with the albums versatility
and flow
but on the whole i see this project as
an improvement over pony on all fronts
and leaves me looking forward to what
rex is going to do next i'm feeling a
light too decent seven on this one tran
position have you given this record a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
it's another video that you can check
out hit that up or the link to subscribe
to the channel anthony fantano rex
orange county uh forever
